clean_story:
"Older brains. New tricks possible. "
"Neuroplasticity after 60. "

The term aging brain flexibility refers to how older brains adapt, rewire, and learn—like a well-worn book still adding new notes.

Most assume memory fades and skills stagnate with age.
But studies show the brain can form new connections—just differently.
A 2018 Harvard study found seniors who learned juggling grew gray matter in motor areas.
Another showed London taxi drivers, memorizing city maps, expanded their hippocampus—even in their 70s.
The key? Repetition + challenge.
Older brains rely more on both hemispheres for tasks, like using two hands to lift a heavy box.
They compensate, not decline.
Three related subjects are memory training methods, bilingualism’s brain benefits, and sleep’s role in learning.
